quote_first: “But I believe,” he pulled out his watch, “I can spend an hour with you. It’s
quote_last: now. If only I’d been something, a landowner, a father, a cavalry officer, a photographer, a journalist … I am nothing, no specialty, and sometimes I am positively bored. I really thought you would tell me something new.”
title: Crime and Punishment
author: Fyodor Dostoyevsky

quote_last: Gunther came back to House Berg with his arms full of yellow daffodils. Frau Julia was Frau Julia again, and she received both him and the daffodils with open arms.
title: Bright Valley of Love
author: Edna Hong

quote_first: The local police wouldn’t relish being called out at
quote_last: on Christmas Eve, and if this was some kind of hoax he preferred not to be an active participant.
title: The Mistletoe Murder
author: P.D. James

quote_first: “I won’t go in,” she says. “I’ll meet you on the steps at
quote_last:
. We can take the girls to Murray’s for a sundae or something.”
He seems relieved. “Right,” he says.
“Tell the children to enjoy themselves.”
title: Life Before Man
author: Margaret Atwood

quote_first: Jonas rolls painfully out of the hammock, his aching lower back stiff and swollen, in desperate need of a chiropractor. He checks his watch.
title: Meg, Primal Waters
author: Steve Alten

quote_first: Sometimes I wonder what happened to the girl—the thought usually pops into my mind when I’m facing a steaming-hot plate of spaghetti. After she hung up, did she disappear forever, sucked into the
quote_last:
shadows? Was I partly to blame?
I want you to understand my position, though. At the time, I didn’t want to get involved with anyone. That’s why I kept on cooking spaghetti, all by myself. In that huge pot, big enough to hold a German shepherd.
title: Blind Willow, Sleeping Woman
author: Haruki Murakami

quote_last: I dash out of the hotel, resolved to make a last-minute stab at it. Just as I turn the corner I brush against Walter Pach. Since he doesn’t recognize me, and since I have nothing to say to him, I make no attempt to arrest him. Later, when I am stretching my legs in the Tuileries his figure reverts to mind.
title: Tropic of Cancer
author: Henry Miller

quote_first: A server is woken at hour
quote_last: by stimulin in the airflow, then yellow-up in our dormroom. After a minute in the hygiener and steamer, we put on fresh uniforms before filing into the restaurant.
title: Cloud Atlas
author: David Mitchell

quote_first: This afternoon everything is matching up. When the swing shift comes on duty the clock says
title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest
author: Ken Kesey

quote_first: I looked at the clock. It was
quote_last: . “Had no idea what hour it was,” Brett said. “I say, can a chap sit down? Don’t be cross, darling. Just left the count. He brought me here.”
title: The Sun Also Rises
author: Ernest Hemingway

quote_last: that afternoon in late January when I stepped into the parlour with Boo, my dog, Hutch was in his favourite armchair, scowling at the television, which he had muted.
title: Odd Hours
author: Dean Koontz

quote_last: , head up to Xclusive where I work out on free weights for an hour, then taxi across the park to Gio’s in the Pierre Room for a facial, a manicure and, if time permits, a pedicure.
title: American Psycho
author: Bret Easton Ellis

quote_first: She hung up on me at first, then asked me whether I made a point of behaving like a ‘small-time suburban punk’ with women I had slept with. But after apologies, insults, laughter, and tears, Romeo and Juliet were to be seen together later that afternoon, mushily holding hands in the dark at a
quote_last: screening of L ove and Death at the National Film Theatre. Happy endings – for now at least.
title: Essays in Love
author: Alain de Botton
